title: Potassium Chloride
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âŒ (Not classified as hazardous under GHS) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): Not classified as hazardous. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ Avoid excessive exposure. â—‹ Handle in accordance with good laboratory practices.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 770 Â°C â— Boiling Point: 1420 Â°C (sublimes at high temp) â— Solubility: 34.2 g/100 mL in water (20 Â°C), insoluble in alcohols â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible 9 â— Other Notes: Commonly used in fertilizers, food (as salt substitute), and medical IV fluids (electrolyte replenisher).
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: General chemical storage (non-hazardous inorganic salts) â— Conditions: Keep container tightly sealed, store in cool dry place â— Container Type: Glass, plastic, or polyethylene containers â— Compatible With: Most inorganic compounds â— Incompatible With: Strong acids (may release HCl gas), strong oxidizing agents
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes, remove contacts if present. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air if dust is inhaled. Seek medical attention if symptoms occur. â—‹ Ingestion: Rinse mouth with water, seek medical advice if large amounts ingested. â— Firefighting: Not flammable. Use extinguishing media appropriate for surroundings. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep up solid, avoid dust generation, place in appropriate waste container.
Lab Use Notes: 10 â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles, dust mask if airborne particles present. â— Handling: Avoid dust inhalation, handle with care to prevent spills. â— Decomposition Products: At very high temperatures may release toxic potassium oxides and chlorine gas. â— Disposal: Dispose of in accordance with local environmental regulations; typically as non-hazardous waste. 11

title: Potassium Nitrate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥â­•, â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames, hot surfaces. â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection/face protection. â—‹ P305+P351+P338: If in eyes: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes. 12
Properties: â— Melting Point: 334 Â°C â— Boiling Point: Decomposes above 400 Â°C (releases oxygen, nitrogen oxides, potassium nitrite) â— Solubility: 31.6 g/100 mL in water (20 Â°C), insoluble in ethanol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer, widely used in fertilizers, food preservation, fireworks, and explosives.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from heat and combustible materials. â— Container Type: Plastic or glass containers resistant to oxidizers. â— Compatible With: Stable with most inorganic salts and metals. â— Incompatible With: Organic materials, sulfur, reducing agents, finely powdered metals, strong acids.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes, seek medical attention if irritation persists. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air, seek medical advice if symptoms occur. 13 â—‹ Ingestion: Rinse mouth with water, seek immediate medical advice. â— Firefighting: Not combustible but supports combustion; use water in large amounts. Do not use dry chemicals or COâ‚‚ extinguishers directly. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep up carefully, avoid dust, place in non-combustible container, wash spill site with water.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, nitrile gloves, chemical splash goggles, dust mask/respirator if dusty. â— Handling: Avoid mixing with combustible or reducing agents. Handle with care to prevent contamination. â— Decomposition Products: Nitrogen oxides (NO, NOâ‚‚), potassium nitrite (KNOâ‚‚), and oxygen gas. â— Disposal: Dispose of in accordance with local regulations. Usually treated as hazardous oxidizer waste. 14

title: Potassium Perchlorate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥â­• (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 2 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â—‹ H335: May cause respiratory irritation. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P370+P378: In case of fire: Use water for extinction. â—‹ P305+P351+P338: IF IN EYES: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes. 15
Properties: â— Melting Point: 610 Â°C (decomposes before boiling) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes on heating (releases oxygen, chlorine oxides) â— Solubility: 1.5 g/100 mL water (25 Â°C) â€” sparingly soluble; insoluble in ethanol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer, less sensitive than potassium chlorate but still hazardous in mixtures. Commonly used in pyrotechnics, explosives, matches, and propellants.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in tightly closed containers in cool, dry, well-ventilated places. Keep away from organic or combustible materials. â— Container Type: Non-combustible, chemical-resistant containers (glass, polyethylene). â— Compatible With: Stable with many inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Sulfur, phosphorus, metals (especially powdered), strong acids, reducing agents, organics.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with water and soap. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes, seek medical advice if irritation persists. 16 â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air, provide oxygen if breathing is difficult, seek medical help. â—‹ Ingestion: Rinse mouth with water, seek immediate medical advice. â— Firefighting: Not combustible itself but releases oxygen; use large amounts of water. Do not use COâ‚‚, dry chemicals, or foam. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust generation, sweep carefully, collect in clean non-combustible containers, wash areas with plenty of water.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, nitrile gloves, chemical goggles, dust mask/respirator in case of airborne particles. â— Handling: Avoid friction, shock, and contamination with combustibles. Handle only with clean tools and surfaces. â— Decomposition Products: Oxygen gas, chlorine oxides, potassium chloride. â— Disposal: Dispose of as hazardous oxidizing waste according to local regulations. Do not mix with organic waste streams. 17

title: Potassium Permanganate
Appearance: Dark purple to almost black crystalline solid, metallic luster, water solutions are
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥â­• (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark), â˜£ (Health hazard), â˜  (Acute toxicity) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 2 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H302: Harmful if swallowed. â—‹ H314: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage. â—‹ H410: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P260: Do not breathe dust/fumes. 18 â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection/face protection. â—‹ P305+P351+P338: IF IN EYES: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes. â—‹ P301+P330+P331: IF SWALLOWED: Rinse mouth. Do NOT induce vomiting.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 240 Â°C (decomposes explosively above 240 Â°C) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes before boiling â— Solubility: 6.4 g/100 mL water (20 Â°C), freely soluble in water with deep purple solution, insoluble in ethanol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer and disinfectant; used in water treatment, analytical chemistry, and as an antiseptic. Decomposes to MnOâ‚‚ and Oâ‚‚ when heated.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, away from organic or easily oxidizable substances. Protect from heat and light. â— Container Type: Glass or plastic containers resistant to oxidizers. â— Compatible With: Most inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Acids, alcohols, glycerol, sulfur, peroxides, powdered metals, strong reducing agents, organic matter.
Safety Notes: 19 â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Immediately wash with plenty of water for 15 minutes; may cause burns and brown stains. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes; seek immediate medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; seek medical attention if irritation persists. â—‹ Ingestion: Rinse mouth, do not induce vomiting, seek immediate medical help. â— Firefighting: Not combustible but accelerates burning; use water spray in large amounts. Avoid dry chemicals or foam. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid raising dust. Sweep up carefully, collect in a clean dry container. Wash contaminated areas with large amounts of water.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Chemical-resistant gloves, safety goggles, lab coat, face shield, dust mask/respirator if airborne particles. â— Handling: Handle with extreme care; avoid contact with organics or reducing agents. Use only with clean equipment. â— Decomposition Products: Oxygen, manganese dioxide (MnOâ‚‚), and potassium oxide. â— Disposal: Treat as hazardous oxidizing waste. Dispose of according to local environmental regulations. Neutralization with reducing agents (like sodium thiosulfate) before disposal may be required. 20

title: Barium Chlorate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: â˜  (Toxic), ğŸ”¥â­• (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark), ğŸŒŠ (Environmental hazard) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 2 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H301: Toxic if swallowed. â—‹ H373: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure. â—‹ H410: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P260: Do not breathe dust. â—‹ P270: Do not eat, drink or smoke when using this product. 21 â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor.
Properties: â— Melting Point: ~414 Â°C (decomposes) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes on heating, does not boil â— Solubility: 27.5 g/100 mL water (20 Â°C), insoluble in alcohol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Powerful oxidizer, used in pyrotechnics (green flame color due to barium). Dangerous because of high toxicity from soluble barium salts.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated place. Keep away from heat, organic materials, and reducing agents. â— Container Type: Glass or compatible plastic container. â— Compatible With: Most stable inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Sulfur, phosphorus, finely powdered metals, strong acids, organic matter, reducing agents.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: 22 â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water. Remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes, seek immediate medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air, provide oxygen if necessary, seek medical attention. â—‹ Ingestion: Extremely dangerous; seek immediate medical attention. Do not induce vomiting. Administer activated charcoal if instructed by medical personnel. â— Firefighting: Not combustible but accelerates burning. Use large amounts of water. Do not use COâ‚‚, foam, or dry chemicals. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Evacuate area, avoid dust formation, sweep up with non-combustible tools, place in a secure container. Wash the area with water. Treat as hazardous waste.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Chemical-resistant gloves, safety goggles, lab coat, dust mask/respirator. â— Handling: Extremely toxic and strong oxidizer. Avoid all exposure to dust and ingestion. Use only in fume hood with proper PPE. â— Decomposition Products: Chlorine oxides, barium oxides, oxygen gas. â— Disposal: Treat as highly hazardous waste. Must not be released into the environment. Dispose of via licensed hazardous waste contractor. âš  Note: Unlike KClOâ‚„ and KMnOâ‚„, barium chlorate combines high oxidizing power with extreme toxicity due to soluble barium. Itâ€™s one of the most hazardous chlorates and rarely used outside specialized pyrotechnics. 23

title: Barium Chromate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: â˜  (Toxic), âš  (Exclamation mark), ğŸ§¬ (Health hazard), ğŸŒŠ (Environmental hazard) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H301: Toxic if swallowed. â—‹ H331: Toxic if inhaled. â—‹ H350: May cause cancer. â—‹ H372: Causes damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure. â—‹ H400: Very toxic to aquatic life. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P201: Obtain special instructions before use. â—‹ P260: Do not breathe dust. 24 â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection/face protection. â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with regulations.
Properties: â— Melting Point: Decomposes above 210 Â°C (releases oxygen and Cr(VI) compounds) â— Boiling Point: Not applicable (decomposes before boiling) â— Solubility: Insoluble in water (~0.0006 g/100 mL at 20 Â°C); soluble in acids â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Used as a pigment (chrome yellow), corrosion inhibitor, and in pyrotechnics. Contains hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)), a known carcinogen.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Toxic inorganic compounds â— Conditions: Store in a tightly sealed container, in a dry, cool, well-ventilated place. â— Container Type: Glass or chemically resistant container. â— Compatible With: Stable with many inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Strong acids (liberates toxic chromium compounds), reducing agents, organic materials.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: 25 â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water, remove contaminated clothing. Seek medical attention if irritation persists. â—‹ Eye: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes, get immediate medical help. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air, provide oxygen if needed, seek immediate medical attention. â—‹ Ingestion: Highly toxicâ€”seek immediate medical attention. Do not induce vomiting. â— Firefighting: Non-combustible but may release toxic chromium oxides if heated strongly. Use water spray. Wear self-contained breathing apparatus. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Evacuate area, avoid dust. Sweep carefully with non-sparking tools. Collect in a sealed container for disposal as hazardous waste. Prevent release to the environment.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, nitrile gloves, safety goggles, respirator if dust risk present. â— Handling: Treat as highly toxic and carcinogenic. Work in fume hood. Prevent release of dust or contaminated water. â— Decomposition Products: Chromium oxides (CrOâ‚ƒ, Crâ‚‚Oâ‚ƒ), oxygen, barium compounds. â— Disposal: Must be disposed of as hazardous waste by a licensed contractor. Do not release it into sewage or the environment. âš  Note: Barium chromate combines the toxicity of soluble barium with the carcinogenic hazard of hexavalent chromium. Its industrial use is now heavily restricted due to health risks. 26

title: Barium Nitrate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥â­• (Oxidizer), â˜  (Toxic), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H301: Toxic if swallowed. â—‹ H373: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure. â—‹ H410: Very toxic to aquatic life with long-lasting effects. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P260: Do not breathe dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. 27 â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 592 Â°C (decomposes) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes before boiling â— Solubility: 36 g/100 mL water (20 Â°C), insoluble in alcohol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer; commonly used in pyrotechnics (green flames), explosives, and in laboratory chemical reactions.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, away from heat, organic matter, and reducing agents. â— Container Type: Glass or compatible plastic container resistant to oxidizers. â— Compatible With: Stable with many inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Sulfur, phosphorus, organic compounds, powdered metals, strong acids, reducing agents.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: 28 â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water. title: Magnesium
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Flammable solid), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 3 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid. â—‹ H261: In contact with water releases flammable gas (hydrogen). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat/sparks/open flames/hot surfaces. â—‹ P223: Keep away from any possible contact with water, because of violent reactions. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P370+P378: In case of fire: Use Class D fire extinguisher or sand. 30
Properties: â— Melting Point: 650 Â°C â— Boiling Point: 1090 Â°C â— Solubility: Insoluble in water; reacts slowly to form magnesium hydroxide â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Light, strong, and commonly used in alloys, fireworks, and flares. Burns with a bright white flame.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Flammable metals â— Conditions: Store in dry, cool, well-ventilated area. Keep away from water, acids, and oxidizers. â— Container Type: Sealed, non-reactive container (e.g., plastic or metal container with desiccant). â— Compatible With: Dry, inert materials. â— Incompatible With: Water, acids, halogens, oxidizers, and moisture.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water. Remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with plenty of water for at least 15 minutes, seek medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air, seek medical attention if irritation occurs. 31 â—‹ Ingestion: Seek medical attention if large amounts ingested; generally low toxicity in small amounts. â— Firefighting: Use Class D fire extinguisher, sand, or dry powder. Do not use water or COâ‚‚. Magnesium fires are extremely intense. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Collect dry with non-sparking tools. Avoid any contact with water.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles, face shield if cutting or grinding. â— Handling: Avoid moisture and sparks. Use tools that will not generate heat or friction. â— Decomposition Products: Magnesium oxide (MgO) when burned. â— Disposal: Collect and store dry. Dispose of as a flammable metal waste according to local regulations. âš  Note: Magnesium metal is highly flammable, especially in powdered or thin ribbon form. Burns with an extremely bright white flame and reacts violently with water. 32

title: Iron
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 1 â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid (in finely divided form, e.g., dust or filings). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat/sparks/open flames. â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust/fumes if iron powder is present. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 1538 Â°C 33 â— Boiling Point: 2862 Â°C â— Solubility: Insoluble in water; soluble in dilute acids with hydrogen gas evolution â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Widely used in construction, steel production, and machinery. Forms rust (iron oxide) when exposed to air and moisture.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Metals, general â— Conditions: Store in a dry, well-ventilated area to prevent corrosion. Keep away from strong acids and oxidizers. â— Container Type: Metal or plastic container; keep dry â— Compatible With: Other dry metals â— Incompatible With: Strong acids, oxidizers, moisture
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes if dust or particles enter eyes. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; iron dust/fumes may cause irritation. â—‹ Ingestion: Generally low toxicity; seek medical advice if large amounts ingested. â— Firefighting: Not easily flammable in bulk. Fine iron powder may ignite; use Class D fire extinguisher or sand. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep up iron filings or powder carefully. Avoid dust inhalation. 34
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles; respirator if handling dust. â— Handling: Avoid creating dust; use appropriate tools for cutting or grinding. â— Decomposition Products: Iron oxide (rust) on corrosion or burning. â— Disposal: Dispose of iron filings or scrap in accordance with local waste regulations. âš  Note: Bulk iron is stable and relatively safe, but fine iron powder is flammable and can form explosive dust-air mixtures. 35

title: Aluminum
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âš  (Exclamation mark), ğŸ”¥ (Flammable solid â€“ fine powder form) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 1 (bulk), 3 (powder) â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid (particularly as fine powder). â—‹ H261: In contact with water, releases flammable gas (hydrogen) â€“ for finely divided forms. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames. â—‹ P223: Keep away from any possible contact with water, due to violent reaction with fine powder. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. 36
Properties: â— Melting Point: 660 Â°C â— Boiling Point: 2470 Â°C â— Solubility: Insoluble in water; reacts slowly with acids and alkalies â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Lightweight and corrosion-resistant metal. Used extensively in aerospace, construction, and pyrotechnics (aluminum powder for flashes or sparks). Burns with bright white flame in powder form.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Flammable metals â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area. Keep away from acids, oxidizers, and water. â— Container Type: Sealed, non-reactive container; keep dry â— Compatible With: Dry, inert materials â— Incompatible With: Water (powder), strong acids, halogens, oxidizers, bases
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for at least 15 minutes if particles enter the eyes. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; aluminum dust may cause irritation. â—‹ Ingestion: Low toxicity in bulk metal; avoid ingestion of powder. 37 â— Firefighting: Use Class D fire extinguisher, dry sand, or special powders. Do not use water or COâ‚‚ on burning aluminum powder. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid creating dust. Sweep up powder carefully with non-sparking tools; collect in a dry container.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles, respirator if dust or powder is present. â— Handling: Avoid creating fine dust; handle only with clean, dry tools. Bulk metal is safe, but powder is highly flammable. â— Decomposition Products: Aluminum oxide (Alâ‚‚Oâ‚ƒ) when burned. â— Disposal: Collect and store dry. Dispose as flammable metal waste according to local regulations. âš  Note: Aluminum metal is generally stable and safe in bulk, but powdered aluminum is highly flammable and reacts violently with water and oxidizers. 38

title: Charcoal
Appearance: Black, porous, brittle solid; powder or lump
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Flammable solid), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 2 (powder can ignite) â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid. â—‹ H260: In contact with water releases flammable gases (if very reactive carbons, e.g., treated charcoal). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames, hot surfaces. â—‹ P240: Ground/bond container and receiving equipment. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection.
Properties: 39 â— Melting Point: Sublimes at ~3550 Â°C; does not melt under normal conditions â— Boiling Point: Decomposes; not applicable â— Solubility: Insoluble in water, soluble in some molten metals and oxidizing acids â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Used as a fuel, in pyrotechnics, as an adsorbent, and in metallurgy (reduction of metals). Fine charcoal dust can form explosive mixtures with air.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Flammable solids / combustible dust â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from oxidizers and sparks. â— Container Type: Sealed, non-combustible container â— Compatible With: Other non-oxidizing solids â— Incompatible With: Strong oxidizers (e.g., nitrates, perchlorates), acids, halogens
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes; remove any particles. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; avoid breathing dust. â—‹ Ingestion: Non-toxic in small amounts; seek medical attention if large quantities ingested. â— Firefighting: Use dry sand, Class D fire extinguisher, or COâ‚‚ for small fires. Charcoal can burn intensely; do not use water on large burning heaps if hot embers may spread. 40 â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust generation; sweep up carefully; store in a dry container away from ignition sources.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling fine powder. â— Handling: Avoid creating airborne dust. Keep away from heat and oxidizers. â— Decomposition Products: Carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚) when burned. â— Disposal: Non-hazardous solid waste; ensure stored away from oxidizers to prevent accidental fire. âš  Note: Charcoal powder is highly flammable and can form explosive dust-air mixtures, especially in confined spaces. Lump charcoal is less hazardous. 41

title: Sucrose
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Flammable solid when finely powdered) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 0 â—‹ Flammability: 1 (bulk), 2 (fine dust) â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid (fine powder can ignite). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames, and hot surfaces. â—‹ P240: Ground/bond container and receiving equipment when handling dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection when handling large amounts of dust.
Properties: 42 â— Melting Point: 186 Â°C (decomposes on further heating) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes at ~160 Â°C under heating (caramelization) â— Solubility: Highly soluble in water (~2000 g/L at 20 Â°C); insoluble in ethanol â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Common sugar; used in food, pharmaceuticals, and pyrotechnics (as a fuel in sugar-potassium nitrate mixtures).
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Combustible solids â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from strong oxidizers. Avoid dust accumulation. â— Container Type: Sealed plastic or glass container â— Compatible With: Other food-grade solids â— Incompatible With: Strong oxidizers (e.g., nitrates, chlorates, perchlorates), acids, heat sources
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Non-irritant; wash with water if needed. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water if dust enters eyes. â—‹ Inhalation: Non-toxic; avoid excessive dust inhalation. â—‹ Ingestion: Generally safe; excessive consumption may affect blood sugar. 43 â— Firefighting: Fine dust may catch fire; use water, COâ‚‚, or dry powder extinguishers for small fires. Avoid dust clouds to prevent dust explosions. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep up dry material; avoid creating dust clouds. Dispose of as non-hazardous solid waste.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, goggles, dust mask if handling powder. â— Handling: Minimize dust generation. Avoid mixing with strong oxidizers or sources of heat. â— Decomposition Products: Carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚), water when burned. â— Disposal: Non-hazardous solid waste; ensure no contact with oxidizers. âš  Note: Bulk sucrose is safe under normal handling, but fine sugar dust is combustible and can form explosive dust-air mixtures. 44

title: Antimony Trisulfide
Appearance: Gray to black crystalline solid, metallic luster
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âš  (Exclamation mark), â˜£ (Health hazard), ğŸ”¥ (Flammable) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 2 â—‹ Flammability: 1 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H302: Harmful if swallowed. â—‹ H315: Causes skin irritation. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â—‹ H335: May cause respiratory irritation. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P302+P352: IF ON SKIN: Wash with plenty of soap and water. 45 â—‹ P304+P340: IF INHALED: Move person to fresh air.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 550 Â°C (sublimes on further heating) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes on heating â— Solubility: Insoluble in water; soluble in hot concentrated acids (e.g., nitric acid) â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Used in pyrotechnics as a fuel in match compositions (e.g., safety matches, glitter compositions) and in some explosives. Combusts with a blue flame.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Flammable solid / hazardous chemical â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, away from oxidizers, acids, and heat sources. â— Container Type: Sealed glass or chemically resistant container. â— Compatible With: Inert materials, dry powders. â— Incompatible With: Strong oxidizers, acids, halogens, and reducing agents.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for at least 15 minutes; seek medical attention. 46 â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; if irritation occurs, seek medical attention. â—‹ Ingestion: Harmful; seek medical advice immediately. â— Firefighting: Use Class D fire extinguisher or dry sand. Avoid water and COâ‚‚ on burning material if in dust form. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid creating dust; sweep up carefully and store in a sealed container. Prevent release to the environment.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles, respirator if dust present. â— Handling: Avoid dust generation and contact with strong oxidizers. Use only with clean, dry tools. â— Decomposition Products: Antimony oxides (Sbâ‚‚Oâ‚ƒ), sulfur dioxide (SOâ‚‚) when heated or burned. â— Disposal: Treat as hazardous waste; dispose according to local regulations. âš  Note: Antimony trisulfide is combustible and toxic. In pyrotechnics, it is valued as a fuel in flash powders and glitter compositions, but extreme care must be taken when handling powdered material. 47

title: Shellac
Appearance: Amber-colored solid or flakes; glossy, brittle
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 2 (dry flakes/powder) â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid (dry flakes or dust may ignite). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames, and hot surfaces. â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection if handling dust.
Properties: â— Melting Point: Softens at ~75 Â°C; melts around 80â€“100 Â°C 48 â— Boiling Point: Decomposes; does not boil â— Solubility: Soluble in alcohols (ethanol, methanol); insoluble in water â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Natural resin secreted by lac insects; widely used as a wood finish, coating, adhesive, and in varnishes. Flammable when dry.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Flammable solids / organic materials â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated place away from open flames and heat sources. Keep flakes dry. â— Container Type: Sealed plastic or glass container â— Compatible With: Other dry, inert materials â— Incompatible With: Strong oxidizers, strong acids, open flames
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Generally non-toxic; wash hands if irritation occurs. â—‹ Eye: Flush with water if flakes/dust enter eyes. â—‹ Inhalation: Avoid inhaling dust or fumes from heated shellac; move to fresh air if irritation occurs. â—‹ Ingestion: Non-toxic in small amounts; seek medical advice if large quantities ingested. â— Firefighting: Flammable; use water spray, COâ‚‚, or dry powder extinguisher for small fires. Avoid dust clouds. 49 â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep dry flakes carefully, avoid dust formation. Collect in a sealed container.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, safety goggles; respirator if handling fine flakes or dust. â— Handling: Avoid dust formation and ignition sources. Keep away from heat and oxidizers. â— Decomposition Products: Carbon oxides (CO, COâ‚‚) if burned; volatile organic compounds if heated. â— Disposal: Non-hazardous solid waste if unburned; ensure not released near ignition sources. âš  Note: Shellac is generally low-toxicity and safe to handle in solid form. Flammability increases if powdered or heated. 50

title: Dextrin
Appearance: White to yellowish powder; odorless, slightly sweet
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: âš  (Exclamation mark), ğŸ”¥ (Flammable dust) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 2 (fine powder can ignite) â—‹ Reactivity: 0 â—‹ Special: â€” â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H228: Flammable solid (fine powder can form combustible dust clouds). â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P210: Keep away from heat, sparks, open flames, and hot surfaces. â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves and eye protection when handling large quantities of dust.
Properties: 51 â— Melting Point: Decomposes above 200 Â°C (caramelizes) â— Boiling Point: Not applicable (decomposes before boiling) â— Solubility: Soluble in water; insoluble in most organic solvents â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Produced from starch by hydrolysis. Commonly used as a binder, adhesive, and thickening agent. Can be used as a fuel in some pyrotechnic compositions when combined with oxidizers.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Combustible solids â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, away from oxidizers and ignition sources. â— Container Type: Sealed plastic or glass container â— Compatible With: Dry, inert solids â— Incompatible With: Strong oxidizers, acids, heat sources
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with water if irritation occurs. â—‹ Eye: Flush with water if dust enters eyes. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; avoid inhalation of dust. â—‹ Ingestion: Generally non-toxic; excessive ingestion may cause digestive discomfort. 52 â— Firefighting: Fine powder may ignite; use water spray, foam, or COâ‚‚ for small fires. Avoid dust clouds to prevent explosion hazards. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Sweep carefully to avoid dust formation; store in a dry container away from ignition sources.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling powder. â— Handling: Avoid creating airborne dust; keep away from oxidizers and heat. â— Decomposition Products: Carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚) when burned. â— Disposal: Non-hazardous solid waste; ensure no contact with oxidizers or ignition sources. âš  Note: Bulk dextrin is generally safe to handle, but fine powder is combustible and can form explosive dust-air mixtures. 53

title: Barium Peroxide
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), â˜  (Toxic), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H301: Toxic if swallowed. â—‹ H373: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure. â—‹ H410: Very toxic to aquatic life with long-lasting effects. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P260: Do not breathe dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. 54 â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 450 Â°C (decomposes) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes before boiling â— Solubility: Slightly soluble in water; reacts with acids to release oxygen â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer used in pyrotechnics and as a source of oxygen. Reacts violently with combustible materials and reducing agents.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from heat, organic matter, and reducing agents. â— Container Type: Glass or compatible plastic container resistant to oxidizers. â— Compatible With: Stable with many inorganic salts. â— Incompatible With: Sulfur, phosphorus, organic compounds, powdered metals, acids, and other strong reducing agents.
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: 55 â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water. Remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for several minutes; seek medical attention if irritation persists. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; seek medical attention if symptoms occur. â—‹ Ingestion: Highly toxic; seek immediate medical attention. Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by medical personnel. â— Firefighting: Not combustible but supports combustion; use large amounts of water. Avoid dry chemical or foam extinguishers directly in large quantities. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust; sweep carefully with non-combustible tools, collect in a clean container, and wash the area with water. Dispose as hazardous oxidizer waste.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, chemical-resistant gloves, safety goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling powder. â— Handling: Avoid contact with combustible materials and reducing agents. Handle only with clean, non-contaminated tools and surfaces. â— Decomposition Products: Oxygen (Oâ‚‚), barium oxide (BaO) on heating. â— Disposal: Dispose of as hazardous oxidizer and toxic waste according to local regulations. Do not release into the environment. âš  Note: Barium peroxide is a strong oxidizer and toxic. It must be handled with extreme care, avoiding all contact with combustible materials, acids, and reducing agents. 56

title: Ammonium Nitrate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 3 (explosive potential under confinement/heat) â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H400: Very toxic to aquatic life. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P234: Keep only in the original container. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations. 57
Properties: â— Melting Point: 169.6 Â°C (decomposes above this temperature) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes; does not boil under normal conditions â— Solubility: Highly soluble in water (~1900 g/L at 20 Â°C) â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Common fertilizer, oxidizer in pyrotechnics and explosives. Can be highly explosive if contaminated with organic material or confined under heat.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from heat, acids, fuels, and reducing agents. Avoid contamination with organic matter. â— Container Type: Original container or compatible plastic/metal container resistant to oxidizers â— Compatible With: Inorganic salts, dry inert solids â— Incompatible With: Combustible materials, fuels, acids, powdered metals, reducing agents
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for 15 minutes; seek medical attention if irritation persists. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; if irritation occurs, seek medical attention. 58 â—‹ Ingestion: Seek medical attention immediately; large amounts can be harmful. â— Firefighting: Not combustible by itself, but supports combustion. Use water spray for fires nearby; avoid using organic extinguishing media. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust; sweep carefully with non-combustible tools. Collect in a clean container, keep away from heat and contaminants.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling powder. â— Handling: Avoid contact with fuels, acids, or reducing agents. Keep dry and uncontaminated. â— Decomposition Products: Nitrogen oxides (NO, NOâ‚‚), oxygen, ammonia, water vapor when heated/decomposed. â— Disposal: Dispose of as oxidizer waste according to local regulations. Do not release into the environment. âš  Note: Ammonium nitrate is a strong oxidizer with potential explosive hazards under confinement, heat, or contamination with fuels. Extreme care must be taken when handling or storing. 59

title: Ammonium Perchlorate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark), â˜£ (Health hazard) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 2 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 3 (explosive potential under heat or confinement) â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â—‹ H335: May cause respiratory irritation. â—‹ H401: Toxic to aquatic life. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. 60 â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations.
Properties: â— Melting Point: 240 Â°C (decomposes) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes before boiling â— Solubility: Soluble in water (~20 g/100 mL at 20 Â°C) â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Commonly used as a solid rocket propellant oxidizer. Highly reactive; can detonate under heat, friction, or confinement.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from heat, fuels, acids, and reducing agents. Keep in the original container and avoid contamination. â— Container Type: Glass or compatible plastic/metal container resistant to oxidizers â— Compatible With: Dry inert solids â— Incompatible With: Organic materials, acids, powdered metals, reducing agents, fuels
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. 61 â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for at least 15 minutes; seek medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; seek medical attention if symptoms occur. â—‹ Ingestion: Toxic; seek medical attention immediately. â— Firefighting: Supports combustion; use large amounts of water to cool containers and nearby combustibles. Do not use dry chemicals directly on bulk material. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust; sweep carefully with non-combustible tools. Collect in a clean container and store safely.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling powder. â— Handling: Avoid contamination with fuels, reducing agents, and organic material. Handle only with clean, dry tools. â— Decomposition Products: Oxygen (Oâ‚‚), nitrogen oxides (NO, NOâ‚‚), hydrogen chloride (HCl) if heated/decomposed. â— Disposal: Treat as hazardous oxidizer; dispose according to local regulations. Do not release into the environment. âš  Note: Ammonium perchlorate is a strong oxidizer and explosive under heat or confinement. Extreme care must be taken in handling, storage, and disposal. 62

title: Sodium Chlorate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 3 (explosive potential with organic materials) â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H302: Harmful if swallowed. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P234: Keep only in the original container. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations. 66
Properties: â— Melting Point: 248 Â°C (decomposes) â— Boiling Point: Decomposes before boiling â— Solubility: Highly soluble in water (~91 g/100 mL at 20 Â°C) â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer used in pyrotechnics, herbicides, and explosives. Can react violently with organic materials, sulfur, and reducing agents.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, away from heat, acids, combustible materials, and reducing agents. â— Container Type: Sealed glass or compatible plastic container resistant to oxidizers â— Compatible With: Dry inorganic salts â— Incompatible With: Organic compounds, sulfur, acids, powdered metals, reducing agents
Safety Notes: â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for at least 15 minutes; seek medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; seek medical attention if irritation occurs. 67 â—‹ Ingestion: Harmful; seek medical advice immediately. â— Firefighting: Not combustible but supports combustion; water spray is recommended. Avoid contact with organic materials. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust formation; sweep carefully with non-combustible tools, collect in a sealed container, keep away from combustibles.

title: Sodium Nitrate
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 1 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 1 (oxidizer) â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P234: Keep only in the original container. â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations.

Extreme care is required during handling, storage, and disposal. 74

title: Strontium Peroxide
Hazard Information: â— GHS Pictograms: ğŸ”¥ (Oxidizer), âš  (Exclamation mark), â˜  (Toxic) â— NFPA 704 Diamond: â—‹ Health: 3 â—‹ Flammability: 0 â—‹ Reactivity: 3 (oxidizer, explosive potential with combustible materials) â—‹ Special: OX (oxidizer) â— Hazard Statements (H-codes): â—‹ H272: May intensify fire; oxidizer. â—‹ H302: Harmful if swallowed. â—‹ H319: Causes serious eye irritation. â—‹ H335: May cause respiratory irritation. â—‹ H410: Very toxic to aquatic life with long-lasting effects. â— Precautionary Statements (P-codes): â—‹ P220: Keep/Store away from combustible materials. â—‹ P261: Avoid breathing dust. 75 â—‹ P280: Wear protective gloves/eye protection. â—‹ P301+P310: IF SWALLOWED: Immediately call a POISON CENTER/doctor. â—‹ P501: Dispose of contents/container in accordance with local regulations.
Properties: â— Melting Point: Decomposes above ~500 Â°C â— Boiling Point: Decomposes; does not boil under normal conditions â— Solubility: Slightly soluble in water; reacts with acids to release oxygen â— Vapor Pressure: Negligible at room temperature â— Other Notes: Strong oxidizer used in pyrotechnics and oxygen generation. Reacts violently with organic materials, reducing agents, and acids.
Handling & Storage: â— Storage Class: Oxidizers (Class 5.1) â— Conditions: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area away from heat, organic materials, fuels, and acids. Keep the container tightly closed. â— Container Type: Glass or compatible plastic/metal container resistant to oxidizers â— Compatible With: Dry inorganic salts, inert solids â— Incompatible With: Organic compounds, strong acids, reducing agents, flammable materials
Safety Notes: 76 â— First Aid: â—‹ Skin: Wash thoroughly with soap and water; remove contaminated clothing. â—‹ Eye: Rinse with water for at least 15 minutes; seek medical attention. â—‹ Inhalation: Move to fresh air; seek medical attention if irritation occurs. â—‹ Ingestion: Toxic; seek immediate medical attention. â— Firefighting: Supports combustion; use large amounts of water to cool surrounding combustibles. Do not use dry chemical extinguishers directly on bulk material. â— Spill/Leak Cleanup: Avoid dust formation; sweep carefully with non-combustible tools. Collect in a sealed container and keep away from heat and combustible materials.
Lab Use Notes: â— PPE: Lab coat, gloves, goggles, dust mask/respirator if handling powder. â— Handling: Avoid contamination with fuels, reducing agents, acids, and organic materials. Handle only with clean, dry tools. â— Decomposition Products: Oxygen (Oâ‚‚) and strontium oxide (SrO) when heated. â— Disposal: Treat as hazardous oxidizer; follow local regulations. Do not release into the environment. âš  Note: Strontium peroxide is a strong oxidizer and can react violently with organic compounds, acids, or reducing agents. Extreme caution is required during handling, storage, and disposal. 77

title: Ethanol
Appearance: Colorless volatile liquid with characteristic odor
Hazard Information: Flammable liquid and vapor (H225). Causes serious eye irritation (H319).
Properties: Melting point: -114 Â°C; Boiling point: 78.37 Â°C; Miscible with water.
Handling & Storage: Keep away from heat/sparks/open flames. Store tightly closed in a cool, well-ventilated place.
Safety Notes: Use non-sparking tools. Wear eye protection and gloves.
Lab Use Notes: Common solvent, disinfectant, and fuel.

title: Acetone
Appearance: Colorless volatile liquid with fruity odor
Hazard Information: Highly flammable liquid and vapor (H225). Causes serious eye irritation (H319).
Properties: Melting point: -95 Â°C; Boiling point: 56 Â°C; Miscible with many organic solvents and water.
Handling & Storage: Keep container tightly closed. Ground/bond container and receiving equipment.
Safety Notes: Avoid inhalation of vapors. Use adequate ventilation.
Lab Use Notes: Widely used solvent and glassware rinse.

title: Isopropyl Alcohol
Hazard Information: Flammable liquid and vapor (H225). Causes serious eye irritation (H319).
Properties: Melting point: -89 Â°C; Boiling point: 82.6 Â°C; Miscible with water and organic solvents.
Handling & Storage: Store away from heat/sparks. Keep container tightly closed.
Safety Notes: Use in well-ventilated areas. Avoid eye contact.
Lab Use Notes: Cleaning solvent and disinfectant.

title: Hydrochloric Acid
Appearance: Colorless to slightly yellow fuming liquid
Hazard Information: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage (H314). Corrosive to metals (H290).
Properties: Strong acid. Reacts with bases and many metals to release hydrogen gas.
Handling & Storage: Store in corrosion-resistant container with resistant inner liner. Keep tightly closed.
Safety Notes: Use acid-resistant gloves, goggles, and face shield. Add acid to water, never water to acid.
Lab Use Notes: pH adjustment, cleaning, and synthesis reagent.

title: Sulfuric Acid
Appearance: Oily, colorless to slightly yellow liquid
Hazard Information: Causes severe burns (H314). Very strong dehydrating agent.
Properties: Boiling point: 337 Â°C (decomposes). Highly exothermic when mixed with water.
Handling & Storage: Store locked up. Keep away from incompatible materials. Always add acid to water.
Safety Notes: Wear acid-resistant PPE; avoid contact with organics and bases.
Lab Use Notes: Catalyst, dehydrating agent, and strong acid.

title: Sodium Hydroxide
Appearance: White pellets, flakes, or granular solid
Hazard Information: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage (H314).
Properties: Strong base. Highly exothermic dissolution in water.
Handling & Storage: Keep container tightly closed. Store away from acids and moisture.
Safety Notes: Use chemical-resistant gloves, goggles, and protective clothing.
Lab Use Notes: pH adjustment, cleaning, saponification.

title: Sodium Bicarbonate
Hazard Information: Not classified as hazardous under GHS.
Properties: Decomposes above 50 Â°C to CO2 and Na2CO3. Slightly alkaline.
Handling & Storage: Store in a cool, dry place. Keep container closed.
Safety Notes: Avoid dust generation. Low toxicity.
Lab Use Notes: Buffering agent, neutralizes acids.

title: Sodium Chloride
Hazard Information: Not classified as hazardous under GHS.
Properties: Melting point: 801 Â°C; Boiling point: 1413 Â°C; Highly soluble in water.
Handling & Storage: General chemical storage. Keep dry.
Safety Notes: Avoid excessive inhalation of dust.
Lab Use Notes: Common electrolyte and reagent.

title: Copper(II) Sulfate
Hazard Information: Harmful if swallowed (H302). Causes skin and eye irritation (H315/H319).
Properties: Soluble in water; aqueous solutions are acidic.
Handling & Storage: Store in a dry place. Keep container closed.
Safety Notes: Avoid release to the environment.
Lab Use Notes: Electrochemistry, education demos, and fungicide.

title: Calcium Carbonate
Hazard Information: Not classified as hazardous under GHS.
Properties: Decomposes above ~825 Â°C to CaO and CO2. Practically insoluble in water.
Handling & Storage: Store in a dry place. Avoid dust.
Safety Notes: Low toxicity. Avoid inhalation of dust.
Lab Use Notes: Filler, buffering agent, and reagent.

title: Acetic Acid
Appearance: Colorless liquid with pungent vinegar-like odor
Hazard Information: Flammable liquid and vapor (H226). Causes severe skin burns and eye damage (H314).
Properties: Boiling point: 118 Â°C; Miscible with water.
Handling & Storage: Keep away from heat and oxidizers. Store in corrosive storage.
Safety Notes: Use appropriate acid-resistant PPE.
Lab Use Notes: Solvent, reagent, and buffer component.

title: Urea
Hazard Information: Not classified as hazardous under GHS.
Properties: Soluble in water; decomposes on heating.
Handling & Storage: Store in a cool, dry place.
Safety Notes: Avoid dust inhalation.
Lab Use Notes: Fertilizer, protein denaturant, and reagent.
